FileList.summary: The FileList interface represents an object of this type returned by the files property of the HTML input element; this lets you access the list of files selected with the <input type="file"> element. It's also used for a list of files dropped into web content when using the drag and drop API; see the object for details on this usage.

This interface was an attempt to create an unmodifiable list and only continues to be supported to not break code that's already using it. Modern APIs represent list structures using types based on JavaScript arrays, thus making many array methods available, and at the same time imposing additional semantics on their usage (such as making their items read-only).

These historical reasons do not mean that you as a developer should avoid FileList. You don't create FileList objects yourself, but you get them from APIs such as , and these APIs are not deprecated. However, be careful of the semantic differences from a real array.
